docs.abstract: By helping at risk children early in their lives, a long-term mentoring program pays society back many times over.
docs.snippet: By helping at risk children early in their lives, a long-term mentoring program pays society back many times over.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Friday, I reported on an organization called Friends of the Children, which identifies children in kindergarten growing up in poverty and facing multiple risk factors at home and in their neighborhood - and then connects them with adult mentors for 12 years. The idea is to guarantee that these children have a consistent relationship with a caring and responsible adult whom they see at least four hours each week, from kindergarten until high school graduation.
docs.abstract: By helping at risk children early in their lives, a long-term mentoring program pays society back many times over.
docs.snippet: By helping at risk children early in their lives, a long-term mentoring program pays society back many times over.

headline.main: A Marathon Runner Delivers a Baby

docs.abstract: Amber Miller, a veteran marathon runner, did not have much time to celebrate after finishing the Chicago Marathon on Sunday: She had a baby to deliver.
docs.snippet: Amber Miller, a veteran marathon runner, did not have much time to celebrate after finishing the Chicago Marathon on Sunday: She had a baby to deliver.

docs.lead_paragraph: A small study suggests that the stress of living in a neonatal intensive care unit affected the brain development of extremely premature infants.

headline.seo: Stress Harms Development of Premature Babies, Study Finds
headline.main: Risks: Stress May Harm Preemies’ Development
headline.print_headline: Risks: Stress May Harm Preemies’ Development

docs.abstract: Study published in journal The Annals of Neurology finds stress of living in neonatal intensive care unit negatively affects brain development of extremely premature infants. Study's senior author is Dr Terrie Inder of Washington University in St Louis.
docs.snippet: A small study suggests that the stress of living in a neonatal intensive care unit affected the brain development of extremely premature infants.

docs.abstract: Ed Sessa rolls out a smooth Tuesday puzzle for us. Oh, and I have a cold.
docs.snippet: Ed Sessa rolls out a smooth Tuesday puzzle for us. Oh, and I have a cold.

docs.lead_paragraph: TUESDAY'S PUZZLE - I have a cold. I'm not sure why I'm telling you this, except that I hope you'll understand if there are mistakes, as I'm currently typing this with my head on my desk. Seeing the entries FEVER and ACHY in the northern part of the grid made me want to nod and say, "Yup", but nodding and saying "Yup" would be too painful, so you'll just have to believe me when I say that they're there. I need to conserve my energy for the rest of the post.
docs.abstract: Ed Sessa rolls out a smooth Tuesday puzzle for us. Oh, and I have a cold.
docs.snippet: Ed Sessa rolls out a smooth Tuesday puzzle for us. Oh, and I have a cold.

docs.lead_paragraph: The existence of the frank new cancer comedy film “50/50” prompts the question, “How did we get here?”

headline.seo: Comedians and Others Are Joking About Cancer

docs.abstract: Jonathan Levine's film 50/50, which stars Seth Rogen and Joseph Gordon-Levitt, is the latest in a series of books, Broadway plays, television shows and movies that explore how people struggling with cancer deal with it in a humorous way.
docs.snippet: The existence of the frank new cancer comedy film “50/50” prompts the question, “How did we get here?”
